awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Medium: Collaborative: Doctor WHO: Investigation and Prevention of Online Content Management System Abuse
awd_abstract_narration:
Over half of the world's 1.8 billion websites run on Content Management Systems (CMS). Unfortunately, CMS deployments make easy targets for attackers, as they are built from an amalgam of layered software and interpreters, with varying degrees of network and system permissions, which execute on an Internet-facing web server. This project develops program-analysis-centric techniques that enable the investigation and remediation of ongoing infections as well as hardening against future CMS compromises, with the goals of 1) understanding the intent and strategy of a CMS infection and tracing their root-cause attack vector for reliable remediation, 2) revealing dynamic and sophisticated attack behaviors in malware samples in a CMS infection, 3) hardening of CMS deployments against future attacks. This project benefits national security and economic stability by creating cyber forensics and vulnerability detection techniques for CMS websites and the financial, government, and private sector operations they support. It provides server-side script code including malicious scripts and vulnerable code to help train next-generation cybersecurity experts. Students from underrepresented minority groups are involved in research activities.

This project develops Doctor WHO, a CMS analysis framework which combines rapid evidence collection and advanced program analysis techniques for the investigation and remediation of infections and hardening against future CMS compromises. Specifically, the data-driven prediction framework, called TARDIS, is developed to understand the temporal correlation of attack evidence across a corpus of real-world websites. TARDIS enables the automated discovery of the artifacts of a compromise, fingerprinting of the attack's propagation, and rapid investigation of cyberattacks against CMS deployments. The project also develops Torchwood, a cross-language and cross-environment program analysis framework to effectively analyze highly dynamic and sophisticated malware targeting CMSs. Torchwood can handle advanced obfuscation and anti-analysis techniques applied to malware and reveal hidden malicious behaviors and intentions of the malware effectively. Lastly, the project develops UNIT that enables the hardening and securing of CMS deployments against future attacks. UNIT accomplishes this by enabling automated dynamic testing of CMS-backed websites without requiring any runtime environment resources. UNIT eliminates false alerts and provide proof-of-concept exploits via a set of new methods to identify and model dependencies of runtime resources and reconstruct missing resources using instrumented script interpreter engines.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
Over half of the world's websites are built upon Content Management Systems (CMS). Unfortunately, CMS deployments make easy targets for attackers. The goal of this project, entitled Doctor WHO, was to develop program-analysis-centric techniques to automatically investigate CMS deployments after a cyber attack and prevent such attacks in the future.

 
Intellectual Merit.  Doctor WHO developed the following unique set of capabilities:


1. Discovery and Investigation of Cyber Attacks on CMS: Our research developed TARDIS, a forensics pipeline that discovers cyber attacks on CMS platforms and recovers the temporal evolution of the attack stages. We applied TARDIS to the nightly backups of 300K websites and found 20,591 attacks which lasted up to 1,694 days. TARDIS's findings were published at the 2020 IEEE Symposium on Security and Privacy. TARDIS revealed that the root cause of many attacks was plugins added to the CMS codebase. We designed YODA, a novel CMS plugin vetting system. YODA uncovered 47,337 malicious plugins on 24,931 unique websites. YODA's findings were published at the 2022 USENIX Security Symposium. Additionally, our research found and cataloged 10.1M obfuscated malware collected from over 27K production websites dating back to 2012. Our work is continuing to identify novel obfuscation and packing techniques used by malware on CMS web servers.


2. Cross-Language Concolic Malware Analysis Engine: During this project, we developed MalMax, a PHP program analysis technique equipped with forced execution capability (or counterfactual execution capability). MalMax identified 1,485 malware samples that were not detected by any existing state-of-the-art tool, even after 7 months in the wild. This work was published and presented at the 2019 ACM CCS conference, a top security conference. Our evaluation of a real-world data set collected from a commercial web hosting company shows that our system, called Cubismo, is highly effective in dissecting sophisticated metamorphic malware with multiple layers of obfuscation. It enables VirusTotal to detect 53 out of 56 zero-day malware samples in the wild, previously undetectable.

We also analyze and detect malicious behaviors on the client's side (e.g., JavaScript). We used this technique to test 352 real-world digital content service providers and discovered 315 flaws from 204 websites, including TIME, Fortune, and Forbes. This work was published in the 2023 International Conference on Software Engineering (ICSE), which is a top software engineering conference.


3. Dynamic Analysis Platform for Hardening CMS: In this project, we observed that static vulnerability scanning techniques for CMS suffer from a high rate of false alarms. Our analysis of popular CMS scanning tools, including PHPScan, Oak, and KPHP, revealed that over 50% of the vulnerabilities they reported were false positives. On the other hand, we found that dynamic analysis tools frequently fail to detect vulnerabilities because of the lack of runtime resources such as a database. When testing databases lacking sufficient data, these tools are unable to reach and identify critical vulnerability points. To overcome these challenges, we developed SynthDB, a novel database generation method tailored for CMS applications with database backends. In tests conducted across 13 real-world PHP applications, including WordPress, phpBB, and OpenCart, SynthDB achieved 63.3% code coverage and 74.5% query coverage. These figures represent a significant improvement, with an increase of 14.4% in code coverage and 21.1% in query coverage, over current state-of-the-art methods. The results of this work were presented at the 2023 Network and Distributed System Security (NDSS) conference.


Broader Impacts. The broader impacts of this project are fourfold:


1. This research directly benefits national security by advancing the state-of-the-art in cyber forensics and vulnerability detection for CMS websites. The PIs worked closely with corporate collaborators to deploy TARDIS, YODA, and MalMax on production websites and remediate the attacks they discovered. 


2. The PIs are committed to the open dissemination of research results. The publications, code, web-hosted services, demos, and tutorials will remain available on PIs' websites and in longer-term archives. The PIs also began commercialization efforts to make these techniques available.


3. The PIs developed new courses and dedicated labs at the graduate and undergraduate levels. This curriculum offers students practical experience with web server malware investigation, forensic log analysis, and program reverse engineering, much of which is drawn from the tools and techniques leveraged in this program. These new teaching materials are also available for the community to use.


4. This project supported workforce development and broadened participation in computing. The research of 7 Ph.D. students, 7 M.S. students, and 2 B.S. students were funded by this research. The Georgia Tech team hosted 40 high school students for a CyberStart America presentation and hosted 6 summer research interns from area high schools, international undergraduate programs, and Georgia State University (GSU).


Last Modified: 02/05/2024
Modified by: Brendan Saltaformaggio
